Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Enabling Technologies for Beyond 1 Tb/s per Wavelength Optical Transport

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Today's photonic infrastructure, whose foundations were established several decades ago, gradually extends from global backbone to access networks and beyond. Recent studies indicate that each household in North America should be connected by at least 100 Mb/s, which cannot be accommodated by the last century's technology. The 100 Gb/s Ethernet is currently under standardization, and according to industry experts 1 Tb/s Ethernet should be standardized by the year 2012-2013. Migrating to higher transmission rates comes along with certain challenges such as degradation in the signal quality due to different linear and nonlinear channel impairments and increased installation costs. The limitations of photonics-enabled networks also result from the heterogeneity of the infrastructure and consequential bottlenecks at different boundaries and interfaces.

This multidisciplinary research grant studies different approaches to overcome the limitations of heterogeneous optical networks and enable serial 1 Tb/s optical transport, while employing the components operating at lower speeds. In this approach, modulation, coding and multiplexing are performed in a unified fashion so that, effectively, the transmission, signal processing, detection and decoding are done at much lower symbol rates. At these lower rates, dealing with nonlinear and linear effects is manageable while the aggregate data rate is maintained at 1 Tb/s and above. The primary research objectives of this grant can be summarized as follows: (i) development of different coded modulation schemes, employing both single-carrier and multicarrier, to enable 1 Tb/s per wavelength optical transport and for simultaneous mitigation of channel impairments over various types of optical links; (ii) hardware FPGA/ASIC implementation of coded modulation schemes; and (iii) validation of the proposed methodology through proof-of-concept implementation studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This multidisciplinary research has been focused on different approaches to overcome the limitations of heterogeneous optical networks and to enable serial 1 Tb/s optical transport and beyond, while employing components operating at comparably much lower speeds. The primary research objectives of this project can be summarized as follows: (i) development of different coded modulation schemes (both single-carrier and multicarrier modulations) to enable 1 Tb/s per wavelength optical transport and to simultaneously mitigate channel impair­ments over various types of optical links; (ii) FPGA implementation of coded modulation schemes; and (iii) vali­da­tion of the proposed methodologies through proof-of-concept experiments.

The overall research resulted in two textbooks and  three book chapters published; two MS thesis defended,  two PhD dissertations defended, over 50 journal papers published, and over 100 conference papers presented and published in corresponding proceedings.

Specific research outcomes include:

  • Implemented: binary LDPC decoder for quasi-cyclic LDPC codes of large (high) girth in FPGA; several nonbinary LDPC decoder algorithms in FPGA; concatenated nonbinary LDPC decoder and outer RS decoder on a single FPGA chip; OFDM transceiver suitable for optical communication in FGPA.
  • Proposed: nonbinary multilevel LDPC-coded modulation of low complexity suitable for optical transport, multiple component codes based generalized LDPC codes suitable for optical transmission, optimum signal constellation design (OSCD) algorithm applicable to optical channels dominated by ASE noise and both linear and nonlinear phase noises; optimum mapping rules for multidimensional signal constellations obtained by OSCD algorithm, inspired by the EXIT chart analysis; staircase rate-adaptive LDPC-coded modulation suitable for high-speed intelligent optical transmission; LDPC-coded TCM-QPSK optical transmission scheme outperforming LDPC-coded BPSK; time-domain-based four-dimensional nonbinary LDPC-coded modulation extending 100G transatlantic optical transmissions; irregular nonbinary QC-LDPC-Coded hybrid multidimensional OSCD-modulation scheme enabling beyond 100 Tb/s optical transports; irregular nonbinary quasi-cyclic LDPC code design employing pairwise block designs (PBDs); multidimensional vector quantization-based signal constellation design enabling beyond 1 Pb/s serial optical transport networks; multidimensional QKD scheme based on combined orbital and spin angular momenta of photon; WDM-TDM NG-PON power budget extension scheme utilizing SOA in the remote node; pragmatic turbo equalizer suitable for optical communications; error-correction coded orbital-angular-momentum modulation suitable for FSO channels affected by turbulence; signal constellation design algorithm suitable for rotationally symmetric optical channels with coherent detection.
  • Developed: a series of spatial-domain-based multidimensional modulation schemes suitable for multi-Tb/s serial optical transmission, a generalized OFDM (GOFDM) scheme for ultra-high-speed optical transmission, reverse concatenated coded modulation for high-speed optical communication, a four-dimensional turbo equalization scheme robust to I-Q imbalance and polarization crosstalk.
